msItem.title: Dated note
msItem.incipit: i versoNo i daye - daye of may ffor my solas 1546

msItem.title: Draft indenture
msItem.incipit: ii recto universi per presentes me est Gwyn pannarius de
msItem.note: Full transcription; text added in the 15th century.

msItem.title: Prayer
msItem.incipit: ii recto Jhesu mercy helpe mary
msItem.note: Full transcription; text added in the late 15th or early 16th century.

msItem.title: Draft letter
msItem.note: Full transcription; text added in the late 15th or early 16th century.

msItem.title: Verse prayer for the King, Queen, and people
msItem.author: John Shirley
msItem.incipit: 1r Lord god preserve vnder þy mighty handes / Oure kyng oure qwene þeyre pepul and þeyre landes
msItem.note: Full transcription. This prayer tag can also be found in two manuscripts copied by Shirley, including p. 359 of Cambridge, Trinity College, MS R.3.20, and f. ii verso of San Marino, Huntington Library, MS EL 26 A 13.

msItem.title: Book curse
msItem.incipit: 1r He that thys Boke renttes or stelle / god send hym sekenys and svart of helle

msItem.title: Troilus and Criseyde
msItem.author: Geoffrey Chaucer
msItem.textLang: Middle English verse with a Latin verse (f. 144r), Latin marginal subheadings, interlinear glosses, incipits and explicits
msItem.incipit: 2r [T]he double sorwe of Troilus to tellen / That was the kyng Priamus sone of Troye
msItem.explicit: 150r So make vs Ihesus for thi mercy digne / ffor loue of Mayde and moder thyne benigne Amen
msItem.note: The text is imperfect due to the loss of a folio after f. 88 (the first leaf of Quire 12), which contained one stanza (III. 1576-82); and two lines (III. 137 and III. 1128) have been left blank, one on f. 65v and another on f. 83v. The scribe has also omitted or their examplar was lacking sections IV. 491-532, 708-14, 1338-1409, and V. 1223-74.

msItem.title: Draft letter
msItem.note: Full transcription; added in the 16th century.

msItem.title: Medical recipe for an enema
msItem.incipit: 151r Take Marcvury a handeful maluse a handfull sallett oyle iij sponfull sallte iij grettis with and sethe the yerbis in clenwater to the yerbis be sode tender then strainid the yerbis and pvte the olee therto and mynister it to the pasient no whotter then ye may suffer yt to yowr cheke - Probatvm
msItem.note: Full transcription as in Rand (2009), p. 7. Added in the late 15th or early 16th century; followed by various incomplete recipes in a different hand.

msItem.title: Pen trials
msItem.note: Drafts of letter openings; added in the 16th century.

msItem.title: Proverb
msItem.incipit: 151v Amen dico vobis quare non creditis michi
msItem.note: Full transcription; added in the (?) 15th century.

foliation.note: Numbering in pencil in the upper right-hand corner of the rectos.
ff. a-d and ff. e-h are modern parchment flyleaves at the beginning and ff. i-ii are original parchment flyleaves at the beginning.

signatures.p: Alphanumeric leaf signatures, consisting of minuscule letters and Roman numerals, throughout but often cropped.

catchwords.seg: Catchwords in brown ink written on the right lower-hand corners of the last versos of quires.

supportDesc.condition: The text has been affected by water or ink droplets on ff. 82v-83r.

layout.seg: Ruled in ink, frame and line ruling. Single columns. 39 lines to the page, written below top line.

handNote.p: The text of Troilus and Criseyde was copied by two scribes writing in a textura quadrata script (Hand 1: ff. 2r-16v and ff. 33r-150r; Hand 2: ff. 17r-32v).
The medical recipe on f. 151r was copied by a 15th- or 16th-century hand working in a script with both secretary and anglicana features.

decoNote.p: Folio 1v features a full-page miniature which shows a man in a wooden pulpit wearing a scarlet cloth addressing a group of seated and standing men and women. This group includes a prince in a gold robe and a lady in diadem against a background of hills and trees. In the right corner of the background there is a pink-coloured turreted castle with a group of people in front of it: this group shows a crowned queen in blue over white and a (?) wreathed king in red in front of it. Before them a prince kneels presenting a gold cap or crown. In the left background and further away, there is dark castle on a rock from which a grop of brightly clad figures descends. The miniature is painted on a gold ground and surmoun5ed by a full border of acanthus leaves in scarlet, blue and pink on a gold ground with extending tendrils, gold besants and coloured leaves.

Many interpretations of this frontispiece exist but scholars generally agree that the man in the pulpit is Geoffrey Chaucer and that the man in gold brocade who immediately stands before him is Richard II (1367-1400) [although others have suggested that he is a later English king or Charles d'Orleans]. For further discussion of the miniature and possible identification of the members in the audience see e.g. Brusendorff (1925); Galway (1949); Williams (1962); Kendrick (1987); Lerer (1993); Scott (1996); Helmbold (2008); Coleman (2010); Helmbold (2010); Carruthers (2014); Howes (2021).

The miniature and borders are thought to have been executed by an English artist who was either trained in France or by a French artist in England [see Scott (2000)]. According to Scott (2000), the same artist worked on the decoration of at least three other extant manuscripts:
Olim Longleat, Longleat House, MS 24
London, British Library, Royal MS 8 G III
Oxford, Bodleian Library MS Auct. F. inf. 1.1

They possibly also worked on the borders in:
London, British Library, Cotton MS Claudius D I
London, British Library, Cotton MS Nero C VI
Paris, Bibliothèque Nationale de France, MS lat. 1196
Ninety spaces for smaller (16 lines, 24/25 lines, or 30/32 lines) miniatures, planned throughout the manuscript but never made (on these planned miniatures see Fisher (1976); Hardmann (1997)).

Spaces for large (7 lines) decorated initials, planned throughout the manuscript but never made. A later (? 15th-century) hand has added three initials by outlining them in brown ink on ff. 2r ('T'), 27r ('O') and 93v ('L'), of which the first features the bust of a man in profile (? Troilus) and the second the bust of a woman (? Criseyde) in brown ink.

Small (1 line) regular initials E in brown ink occasionally decorated with dog heads. E.g. see line 6 on f. 4r; lines 13 and 17 on f. 5r; and line 31 on f. 9r. The final rubricated explicit on f. 150r contains, alongside a dog head, a human face (on the dog heads, see Kennedy (2022), passim).
Incipits and explicits to the different books written in red ink.

note.p: A corrector has added the note deficit to the margins of ff. 22r, 65v, 80v, and 83v, but the manuscript was apparently not returned to the scribes for making emendations.
A title inscription has been added by a 15th-century hand to f. i verso: Thys ys the Booke of Troilus and Criseyde.

A Middle English verse on the manuscript's contents (now partially erased) has been added added by a 15th-century hand to f. ii recto: [...] Boke of Troylus and Cryseide / [good fortune in hevyn] to abyde (DIMEV 884).
An erased description of the manuscript or ownership inscription has been added by a late 15th-century hand on f. 151r: This boke his [...].
A later 15th-century reader has added the note deficiut [sic] vi balettes to f. 100v.
Quire numbers in pencil have been added to the lower right-hand corners of the first rectos of quires by a modern (20th-century) hand.

binding.p: Modern red goatskin over (?) older wooden boards with six raised bands on the spine (but no title or classmark inscriptions) by the Cambridge Colleges Conservation Consortium, 1994.

origin.p: The manuscript has been variously dated based on palaeographical and decorative grounds but most scholars agree that the manuscript must have been produced at some point between 1385 and 1425: c. 1385-1456 (Parkes (1978)); c. 1398 (Seymour (1992); (1995)); after 1415-before 1425 (Scott (2000)); c. 1415-c. 1425 (De Hamel (2005)); c. 1415-c.1420 (Nichols (2008)); c. 1400-1415 (Coleman (2010)); 1385-1413 (Mooney, Horobin and Stubbs (2011)); 1400-1450 (Rand (2009)).

provenance.p: Edward Franton [? Frampton] (fl. 15th century) Franton [? Frampton], Edward, fl. 15th century: owned or accessed the manuscript. His name is written in reverse (Notnarf drawde) on a decorative banderol on f. i verso, on f. 147r and f. 151r.
John Shirley (1366?-1456) Shirley, John, 1366?-1456, author, translator, and scribe: owned or accessed the manuscript. He added a Middle English verse prayer to f. 1r.

Anne Neville (fl. 15th century) Neville, Anne, fl. 15th century: owned or accessed the manuscript. Her name is inscribed in the outer margin of f. 101v: Neuer foryeteth Anne Neuyll. Unidentified, but scholars have proposed various identities: one is Anne Beauchamp (1426–1492), 16th Countess of Warwick, and wife of Richard Neville, 16th Earl of Warwick, on the basis that the manuscript was once also accessed by the scribe John Shirley (1366-1456) [see above], whose main patron was Anne's father, Richard Beauchamp, 13th Earl of Warwick [for this identifciation, see Parkes (1978), p. 12; Connolly (1998), 41, 109-110; Driver (2007), pp. 181-182; on Ann Beauchamp, see Scott (1976), pp. 61-63]. Another candidate is Anne Neville (c. 1410-1480), daughter of Joan Beaufort and Ralph Neville, Duke of Westmorland, and wife to Humphrey Stafford, 1st Duke of Buckingham [see Vines (2011), pp. 22-25]. This identification is suggested by the name inscription Knyvett on f. 108r (see below). The latter may be William Knyvett (1440-1515), Sheriff of Norfolk and Suffolk, whose third wife was Joanna Stafford, one of Anne Neville's daughters. If this second identification is accepted, then it is possible that the manuscript passed down to Joan Stafford and William Knyvett.

Knyvett (fl. 15th century) Knyvett, fl. 15th century: a member of the Knyvett family owned or accessed the manuscript. Their family name written upside down in the outer margin of f. 108r. Unidentified, but perhaps William Knyvett (1440-1515), Sheriff of Norfolk and Suffolk, if the identification of the Anne Neuyll whose name is inscribed in the outer margin of f. 101v as Anne Neville-Stafford (c. 1410-1480) [see above] is accepted: her daughter, Joan Stafford, married William Knyvett in 1477. On the Knyvetts as book owners, see David McKitterick, The Library of Sir Thomas Knyvett of Ashwellthorpe (Cambridge: Cambridge University Library, 1978).

Dorothy Pennell [Pernell / Pennett / Pernett] (fl. 15th or 16th century) Pennell [Pernell / Pennett / [Pernett], Dorothy, fl. 15th or 16th century: owned or accessed the manuscript. Her name is written in the outer margin of f. 63r but is heavily erased and difficult to read with UV light: Dorete P[ennell].

Henry Coldvell [? Coldwell] (fl. 15th or 16th century) Colvell [? Coldwell], Henry, fl. 15th or 16th century: owned or accessed the manuscript. His name written at the top of f. 151r: Hanrycum Coldvell. Unidentified, but perhaps the same Henry Coldwell who inscribed his name on the title page (Hanricum Coldwell) and twice more on the final page (Per me Hanricum Coldewell and -cum coldewell [cropped]) of Raoul Lefèvre, The veray trew history of the valiaunt knight Iason how he conqueryd or wan the golden fles. by the Counsel of Medea. and of many othre victoryouse and wondrefull actis and dedys that he dyde by his prowesse and cheualrye in his tyme (Antwerp: Gerard Leeu, 1492) (now Cambridge, University Library, Inc.3.F.6.2[3396] [formerly AB.10.54(2)]).

Wlliam Carye [Carie] (d. 1572/3) Carye [Carie], William, d. 1572/3, London clothworker and book collector: he probably is the Mr Cari who, according to an ex dono inscription on f. 150v gave the manuscript to Stephen Batman (see below) on 17 December 1570. On William Carye, see A. G. Watson, 'Christopher and William Carye, Collectors of Monastic Manuscripts and "John Carye"', The Library, 20 (1965), 135-142.

Stephen Batman [Stephan Bateman] (1541-1584) Batman [Bateman], Stephen [Stephan], 1541-1584, Church of England clergyman and author: his ownership inscription on f. 150v: This is my booke / S. B. / geven to me by Mr Cari the xvij of december Anno / 1570 / ex dono. Batman was a member of the household of Matthew Parker (1504-1575), archbishop of Canterbury, and claimed to have collected 6,700 books for him.

Matthew Parker (1504-1575) Parker, Matthew, 1504-1575, archbishop of Canterbury: the manuscript is recorded as Troilus of Chaucer among the libri in minore Bibliotheca on f. 42v of his register of books, now Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 575 [see M.R. James (1912), I, p. xxxiv].

acquisition.p: Presented to Corpus Christi College by Matthew Parker (1504-1575) Parker, Matthew, 1504-1575: The number 61 inscribed in pencil on the inside of the front cover. Listed as item no. 17 (Troylus Chauceri Anglicè, cum pictura suauissima) in Thomas James's Ecloga Oxonio-Catabrigiensis, printed in London in 1600. Item no 1293 / no. 17 in Edward Bernard and Humfrey Wanley, Catalogi librorum manuscriptorum Angliæ et Hiberniæ, in unum collecti, cum indice alphabetico printed in Oxford in 1697. Item no. B.5 (Troylus Chauceri Anglicè in pergameno; manu optimâ) in William Stanley, Catalogus librorum manuscriptorum in Bibliotheca Collegiis Corporis Christi in Cantabrigia: Quos legauit Matthaeus Parkerus Archiepiscopus Cantuariensis, printed in London in 1722 (see also the inscription B.5 on f. ii recto). Item 61 in James Nasmith, Catalogus librorum manuscriptorum quos Collegio Corporis Christi et B. Mariae Virginis in Academia Cantabrigiensis legauit Reverendissimus in Christo Pater Matthaeus Parker, Archiepiscopus Cantuariensis printed in Cambridge in 1777.

recordHist.source: This catalogue entry draws on M.R. James, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Manuscripts in the Library of Corpus Christi College, Cambridge, 2 vols (Cambridge, 1912), no. 61; and Kari Anne Rand, Manuscripts in the Library of Corpus Christi College, Cambridge, The Index of Middle English Prose, Handlist XX (Cambridge: Brewer, 2009), pp. 88-90. Images and a description of the manuscript are also available on the Parker Library website: the online catalogue entry for the item published at Parker on the Web Corpus Christi College, MS 61.

availability.p: Visitors to Corpus Christi College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Parker Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Parker Library: Information for Readers.

listBibl.bibl: For a bibliography for this item maintained by Corpus Christi College Cambridge see: Cambridge, Corpus Christi College, MS 61: Zotero Bibliography
